description: Elevator safety circuits, interlocks, and protective devices

questions.question: What is the purpose of the elevator safety circuit?
options: Prevent operation when unsafe conditions exist
questions.explanation: The safety circuit is a series circuit that prevents elevator operation when any safety device detects an unsafe condition.

questions.question: How are safety devices typically wired?
options: In series so any open device stops operation
questions.explanation: Safety devices are wired in series so opening any device breaks the circuit and stops elevator operation.

questions.question: What is an interlock in elevator systems?
options: Device preventing operation unless doors are closed and locked
questions.explanation: Interlocks are devices on hoistway doors that prevent elevator operation unless doors are properly closed and locked.

questions.question: What is the function of a pit stop switch?
options: Remove power from safety circuit when personnel in pit
questions.explanation: The pit stop switch allows personnel to disconnect elevator power when working in the pit for safety.

questions.question: What is a governor?
options: Overspeed sensing device that triggers safeties
questions.explanation: The governor is a centrifugal device that senses overspeed and triggers the car safety device to stop descent.

questions.question: What happens when the governor trips?
options: Governor rope grips, activating car safety to stop the car
questions.explanation: When tripped, the governor grips its rope, which pulls the safety mechanism to engage the guide rails and stop the car.

questions.question: What is a buffer?
options: Device in pit to stop car or counterweight at terminal
questions.explanation: Buffers are devices at the bottom of the hoistway that stop the car or counterweight if they over-travel.

questions.question: What is the car top stop switch used for?
options: Allows mechanics to stop car from car top during maintenance
questions.explanation: The car top stop switch allows maintenance personnel to remove power for safety while working on the car top.

questions.question: What is the typical governor overspeed tripping speed?
questions.explanation: Governor overspeed switches trip at 115% of rated speed maximum, before the safety device setting.

questions.question: What is the difference between Type A and Type B safeties?
options: Type A has gradual stopping; Type B for instantaneous stopping
questions.explanation: Type A safeties provide gradual (flexible guide clamp) stopping; Type B provides instantaneous stopping.

questions.question: What is unintended car movement (UCM) protection?
options: Device preventing car movement with doors open outside the landing zone
questions.explanation: UCM protection prevents dangerous car movement when hoistway doors are open and car is outside the door zone.

questions.question: What electrical device prevents car movement until motor field is established?
questions.explanation: The motor field relay prevents brake release until adequate motor field current is established for control.

questions.question: What is the function of the final terminal stopping device?
options: Backup that stops car if normal terminal devices fail
questions.explanation: Final terminal stopping devices are backup switches that stop the elevator if normal terminal devices fail.

questions.question: What is a car door bypass device?
options: Device allowing movement with car doors open under specific conditions
questions.explanation: Car door bypass allows limited movement with car doors open for releveling or inspection purposes.

questions.question: What is the emergency stop switch in the car?
options: Device that stops elevator and opens safety circuit when activated
questions.explanation: The emergency stop switch opens the safety circuit to immediately stop elevator travel when activated.

questions.question: What is a broken rope or chain switch?
options: Device detecting slack or break in suspension members
questions.explanation: This device detects abnormal slack or breakage in suspension ropes/chains and opens the safety circuit.

questions.question: What is machine brake monitoring?
options: Electrical monitoring that brake is properly engaged before releasing power
questions.explanation: Brake monitoring verifies the brake is properly engaged before elevator power is removed for parking.

questions.question: What is ascending car overspeed protection (ACOP)?
options: Additional protection against overspeed in the up direction
questions.explanation: ACOP provides protection against overspeed during ascent, typically using counterweight safeties or rope brakes.

questions.question: What is a compensating chain/rope switch?
options: Device detecting issues with compensating chains or ropes
questions.explanation: This switch detects problems with compensating chains or ropes (excessive sway, breakage) and stops the car.

questions.question: What happens when safety circuit opens during operation?
options: Motor power removed and brake applied immediately
questions.explanation: Opening the safety circuit removes motor power and applies the brake to immediately stop the elevator.

questions.question: What is redundancy required for safety-related control functions?
options: Two independent means required (electrical AND mechanical)
questions.explanation: Critical safety functions require two independent means of protection (typically electrical and mechanical).

questions.question: What is a monitored safety circuit?
options: Circuit using two channels with cross-monitoring for fault detection
questions.explanation: Monitored safety circuits use two channels that cross-check each other to detect failures or faults.

questions.question: What SIL (Safety Integrity Level) applies to elevator safety functions?
questions.explanation: Critical elevator safety functions typically require SIL 3 rating per functional safety standards.

questions.question: What is the principle of fail-safe design in elevator circuits?
options: Failure of any component results in safe condition (stopped)
questions.explanation: Fail-safe design ensures that component failures result in the elevator stopping rather than dangerous operation.

questions.question: What is contact monitoring in safety relays?
options: Verification that relay contacts have changed state as commanded
questions.explanation: Contact monitoring verifies relay contacts have properly opened or closed, detecting welded or stuck contacts.

questions.question: What is required for electronic safety circuits?
options: Type-tested and certified for safety-related applications
questions.explanation: Electronic safety devices must be type-tested by an accredited lab and certified for safety-related use.

questions.question: What is PESSRAL?
options: Programmable Electronic System in Safety-Related Applications for Lifts
questions.explanation: PESSRAL covers requirements for programmable electronic systems used in elevator safety applications.

questions.question: What is the cross-checking requirement for dual-channel safety circuits?
options: Automatic comparison of both channels at each operation cycle
questions.explanation: Dual-channel systems must automatically compare both channels at each cycle to detect discrepancies.

questions.question: What protection is required against single ground faults?
options: Single ground fault must not cause unsafe operation
questions.explanation: Safety circuits must be designed so a single ground fault cannot cause unsafe operation or bypass safety devices.

questions.question: What is required when software controls safety functions?
options: Safety-rated software meeting functional safety standards with verification
questions.explanation: Safety-related software must meet functional safety standards (IEC 61508) with proper verification and validation.
